semantic_title: Use of Symptom Codes for Reporting
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 18. Chapter 18: Symptoms, signs, and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified (R00-R99) > a. Use of symptom codes

content.full_text: Codes that describe symptoms and signs are acceptable for reporting purposes when a related definitive diagnosis has not been established (confirmed) by the provider. (Evidence: pg no: 75, L84-L85)
content.summary: Symptom and sign codes are acceptable for reporting when a definitive diagnosis has not been established by the provider (Evidence: pg no: 75, L84-L85)
key_concepts: Symptom and sign codes acceptability (Evidence: pg no: 75, L84)
Definitive diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 75, L85)
Provider confirmation requirement (Evidence: pg no: 75, L85)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Symptom and sign codes are acceptable for reporting when definitive diagnosis not established (Evidence: pg no: 75, L84-L85)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a provider has not confirmed or established a definitive diagnosis, it is appropriate and acceptable to use codes that describe the presenting symptoms and signs (Evidence: pg no: 75, L84-L85)
common_applications: Emergency department visits with undetermined diagnosis

workflow_steps: Step 1: Review provider documentation for definitive diagnosis
Step 2: If no definitive diagnosis established, identify symptoms/signs
Step 3: Select appropriate R00-R99 codes for symptoms/signs
Step 4: Assign symptom codes as appropriate for encounter
